it is not good to listen to all music is
better old music is good hey shut it up
shut it up you oh man it's late because
this mount jiri album has been keeping
me up hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest
music nerd tired but passionate still
and ready to do an album review Mount
Erie clear moon mount Erie is the self
recording project of singer-songwriter
Phil elrom who once recorded under the
name the microphones and put out some of
his best material under that moniker the
globe part 2 the mount Erie album itself
before he went on to change the name of
his project and it was hot we stayed in
water but under the Mount Erie name to
fill has been putting out some fantastic
music whether Phil is singing side by
side with one of his musical influences
Jew lead Warren on the lost wisdom album
or if he's embarking on some
directionless abstract bare raw acoustic
songwriting on the album dawn right
there a series of tracks he wrote while
in isolation in a cabin in Norway during
a winter from 2002 to 2003 whether he's
doing what are doing the other he's
captivating me I even followed him on
his black opening EP where he was
laudanum his songs with sounds from the
world of hardcore punk and he got even
louder on one of his last full-length
albums winds pomor he was incorporating
elements of black metal into his music
over the years i mean phil has just
become one of my favorite songwriters
however it's really difficult
for me to justify that to other people
because he does not go by the same rules
as most singer-songwriters he doesn't
shoot for the same goals he doesn't try
to make the same accomplishments which
can be a blessing and a curse
his music is just undeniably unique but
what might bother some people is that
sometimes his songs are extremely long
or drawn-out sometimes they're very
short and have abrupt endings that come
out of nowhere rarely do they ever
adhere to a verse chorus verse structure
and lyrically most of Phil's songs are
obsessed with things like death life
nature like literally nature like
getting down to the specifics of of
rocks and streams and wind and trees and
mountains fog and oceans as well
showcasing this very deep emotional and
and almost spiritual connection that
phil has with these things some - some -
sometimes talking about these things so
compulsively it feels as if phil is
inventing his own kind of world where
these things exist outside of the rest
of modern society and when film mentions
these things or this other world where
these things exist he does not talk
about how they inspire him emotionally
in a very explicit way or anything like
that he keeps his lyrics very obtuse he
does this so consistently that his music
seems like this intentional challenge to
the listener to get some kind of deeper
meaning out of what he's saying and
follow him down this dark wooded path
into this forest like abyss and then
just get stuck in this other world like
like he is and what makes Mount Erie
even more unique is just phil el room's
production style the way he records
mixes and just produces his music he
loves panning the acoustic guitars left
and right wildly he also
mixes his very shy voice notoriously low
especially when the instrumentation
surrounding the vocals is getting loud
and for the most part instrumentally
filled deals in a lot of soft and
acoustic sounds but they still manage to
have a very kind of rugged quality to
them but when Mount Airy does manage to
put out a piece of music that is loud
and is distorted and is abrasive it is
going to be one of the most rough
tumbles you've ever had with music
period which brings me to this new not
Irie LP clear moon fill al-rahman this
album goes for roughly the same
experience that you will get with just
about any Mount URI album but approaches
it from a different direction and what
that overall feel of this album is that
I feel nearly every Mount URI album
shares is just that feeling of water
tutoring with no real direction or
purpose into a forest on a moonlit night
this music just has a real sense of
isolation and distance from the usual
everyday lives that most of us live and
that is spelled out perfectly with the
opening track which has these really raw
acoustic guitars being strummed very
hypnotically
playing these beautifully embellished
chords some soft drums very deep bass
jeroni keyboards it's a slow-growing
ballad with the instrumentation getting
more dramatic toward the end of the song
especially with these clanging bells
toward the end of the track that are a
really nice touch
the next track down here is even more
beautifully produced the place lives
where it sounds like Phil did about 12
or so takes of him strumming these
guitar chords and then layered them over
one another through some effects on a
minute ended up sounding kind of like a
guitar Orchestra like this wall of
chords that really don't even resemble
guitars anymore there's distorted guitar
on the track with shots of feedback
coming in here and there
but that guitar is mixed quietly in the
mix as well as the drums - and over that
some very light airy keyboards just
another example of how weird the mixing
can be on a Mount Erie album the track
house shape has a very repetitive
quality to it especially with the
drumming and in a way kind of feels like
krautrock a little bit and I love how
the since they're just kind of like a
rollercoaster going up and down in
volume so fast and it just makes this
track feel so hypnotic the track over
dark water has this really nasty
distorted rumbling set of guitars bass
as well and it is just a rough sandpaper
rough but that kind of fades away a
little bit and gives weight to these
vocals both Phil's vocals and some
female vocals as well later - over one
another in this just beautiful chorus
that is almost gospel like it is a
religious experience just around the
middle point of this album the title
track on here is a vocally fronted drone
Odyssey that lasts seven minutes the
longest track on this album 50 Phil
actually Auto Tunes his own background
vocals and layers them with some
untreated lead vocals in a pretty bony
ver kind of way
overall with clear moon Phil elrom
manages to change things up do something
slightly new for longtime fans but still
keeps his style very potent very
experimental and enchantingly strange
for newcomers there are some surprising
moments on here like the sinister
saxophones toward the end of the track
lone Belle but the biggest change on
this album is the overall tone and the
use of synthesizers in comparison with
winds poem which really was a storm this
is way more serene I think this is the
most serene album Phil has dropped under
the name mount Erie so far and it's all
because of the sense
it's come to fruition because of the
sins which come in and thicken a lot of
these tracks up to the point where they
pretty much are drones I mean this album
even ends with a three-minute long since
piece that kind of burns things out like
a dying candle nearly every track on
here has a drone equality to it whether
it starts as a drone or it progressively
grows into one toward the tracks end as
far as gripes go there are some songs on
here like lone Bell that I wish had a
little bit more detail to them
especially with the horn phrase toward
the end getting a little repetitive just
a little over long and in comparison
with winds poem and and then other Mount
Airy albums as well this album is
definitely not that urgent or that
gripping I don't see myself putting it
on as often as other Mount
Erie LPS though it is really beautiful
for I see people who are more attracted
to drone and ambient music gravitating
toward this I'm feeling a strong 7 to a
light 8 on this LP thought it was great
but uh what did you guys think of it did
you love it
did you hate it why and what should I
review next anthony Fantana thank you
